learning_outcomes.description: Understand the challenges in creating and implementing innovative ideas.
Demonstrate a thorough understanding of how uncertainty impacts the innovation process.
Demonstrate awareness of how ideas and other forms of intellectual property can be protected.
Apply critical thought skills and course content to real case examples in collaborative teams and present your findings in oral and written form.
Demonstrate knowledge and respect of ethics and ethical standards in relation to global idea management.

assessments.due_date:
30/03/2026 10:00 am

This exam will be administered in the timetabled seminar
assessments.task_description:
Students are expected to understand and critically reflect upon threshold and foundational concepts and activities of idea management in this mid-semester examination. The exam will consist of multiple choice questions and a case study reflection. This 2-page case study will be provided during the exam.

More details will be provided on Blackboard.

AI Statement

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This is a paper-based exam administered during timetabled the seminar for the course. Students will be provided with an MCQ answer sheet and a 7-page exam booklet.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
For this assessment, students will be required to undertake one (1) excursion on Mondays in Weeks 8-9, choosing from one (1) of four (4) excursions available. Students will choose which excursion they can attend and first come, first served basis.

These excursions will visit a number of emerging technology firms who are part of Uniquest's portfolio (https://uniquest.com.au). These firms are located in Brisbane and can be accessed by students and the teaching team by public transport. More details will be provided in-class and on Blackboard.

The excursions have been designed for students to obtain a practical perspective to the study of innovation and idea management. Students are expected to maintain a notebook/logbook of their excursion using a template provided to students. This notebook/logbook should be used as the basis of a critical reflection upon both the theory and practice of idea management so the quality of note taking, attention to detail, and keen observations will be assessed. This notebook/logbook section is worth 20% and should be included as an appendix to the reflection.

Students are required to submit a 1200-word reflection as the body of the submission. The reflection should critically reflect upon the enablers, obstacles, and dynamics of innovation they have observed. and how this connects with scholarly approaches of idea management presented in the course. Students are expected to annotate relevant excursion observations in the body of the reflection, as well as in-text referencing from 3-5 well-justified scholarly references. This reflection section is worth 20%. A template reflection will be provided to students.

AI Statement:

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
Week 12, 10:00 am

This assessment will be administered in the timetabled seminar
assessments.task_description:
This assignment encourages students to apply course concepts and theories in a hackathon style experience delivered during the Week 12 seminar. This is a practical exercise for students who in teams will appraise an emerging technology and provide recommendation on how to bring this technology to the market and to develop strategies for greater market penetration and/or coherence. Student teams must also consider ethical considerations when engaging a customer groups, organisations, and the community in general.

Students will be randomly formed into teams of five (5) students in Week 11 and are expected to collaborate and communicate together in the hackathon experience in Week 12.

Student teams will be provided a client brief at the beginning of the seminar and are expected to rigorously discuss the client brief, appraise opportunities and challenges, and complete a Business Model Canvas (BMC) as a deliverable of this hackathon experience. Additionally, the team should choose one (1) team member who will give a 2-minute elevator pitch of their proposed solution and strategy to the teaching team.

Each team member is expected to make an equal contribution in the hackathon. At the end of the presentation, all team members will be required to complete a peer assessment of each other's performance and contribution to the evaluation. Instructions for how to do this will be provided in class.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will be provided with relevant materials in the seminar. These materials will be collected at the end of the seminar.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Late submissions are not accepted for in-class presentations. Failure to present at the scheduled time will result in a mark of zero for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Innovation excursions

Weeks 7-9 are focussed on experiencing idea management in real life.

In Week 7, we will have a guest lecture from Uniquest and an on-campus excursion to help prepare students for off-site excursion in the timetabled seminar slot of 10am-1pm.

Students are then required to attend one (1) of four (4) excursions planned across Weeks 8-9.

On the Monday of Week 8, two excursions will leave from St Lucia campus at 8am, visiting up to two firms in Brisbane and aiming to return to campus by 1pm.

On the Monday of Week 9, two excursions will leave from St Lucia campus at 8am, visiting up to two firms in Brisbane and aiming to return to campus by 1pm.

Each excursion will be capped at a specific number of students. Students will be allocated a spot on the excursion on a first come, first served basis. A Padlet will be provided for sign-up.

The purpose of the field trip is to experience the opportunities and the challenges of idea management first hand and visiting firms in the Uniquest portfolio

More details about the logistics of these field trips will be provided in class.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
